No wonder a woman can be attacked in broad day light and no one would help her, with some folks like some of you that defend this type of irresponsible behavior on a PEACE officer that is suppose to be SERVING his communities, not being a SS guard to it. But I keep forgetting, we are now in a police state and we are there to serve them, not the other way around. Although I disagree with the way the officer handled this case, he technically was correct. Again experience of the officer comes into contention. Conducting a traffic stop is basically for all purposes an arrest. Depending on the policy of his department (even though the Chief disapproved of this officers actions) they may have well been in line with policy. Stop the offender, Verify credentials, release on summons. Five minutes max in most cases. If the driver/passenger just complied with officer instructions it probably would have gone a lot faster. Both the occupants in the car could have done a lot to help the situation instead of the way they behaved. Both parties are at fault, although I understand the family members are emotionally upset, their best course of action instead of arguing with the officer would be to calm down are state their case, that would take the officer off the defensive and put him into a better mindset to help these people. The Officers experience is what led him to respond this way. Since no one here can speak to that we just don't know. I don't believe this case alone will result in the officers termination because technically he did nothing wrong, he'll probably will just wind up going to get some sensitivity training or some garbage like that. Although I think his behavior could have been done differently, he won't be fired unless that PD can show where the officer was trained to respond differently or the officer is on probation or has a long history of behavioral issues. This is not a police state, far from it. This officer was indeed serving his community in some cases that means causing inconvenience to individual citizens by detaining/arresting them. It's the overall mission to make the community safer.

content: It's pretty easy to monday morning quarterback the guy on the street. shuman14 and CombatNAC have pretty good handle on the reality of the situation. In hind sight the officer may even second guess himself. What most don't realize, especially those that regularly spew the anti police, anti law, anti gonverment garbage and turn every situation into a political argument, is that officers are regularly faced with very fluid situations and are required to make decisions in an instant. If you have ever been jumped or ambushed on the streets of your own city while doing what some would call routine stops. You might have a insight into the process. Your decision making is centered around your own safety first. Then if your sure of that you can allow others in the situation some latitude. When people are emotionally charged they can and will do just about anything. When an officer is on scene that officer will take control of the immediate area whether you like it or not. The more crap you give them the less likely they are to relinquish that control. Officers do get very tired of excuses. Just because we call this a free country does not mean you can do whatever you want if you think you have a good escuse. The stop was ligitamate. Is the officer going to take some heat for getting bad press, probably. Is the officer going to get fired over it, I doubt it. Unless you can come up with a crystal ball for officers to carry around all the time, you are just going to have realize, that sometimes things aren't going to go the way you would like them to in your perfect little world. As far as "protect and serve" that refers to the best interest and safety of the general public. If you are on the wrong side of that generally your not going to like the outcome. The military is full of people that say if you haven't BTDT your opinion is of little value. Same applies here.
